questions.text: An 81-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter after being found wandering on the street. His daughter says that over the past several months he has been more aggressive towards friends and family. She also reports several episodes in which he claimed to see two strangers in her apartment. He sometimes stares blankly for several minutes and does not react when addressed. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 10 months ago. His current medications include carbidopa-levodopa, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place and time. There is a resting tremor in his right upper extremity. There is muscle rigidity in the upper and lower extremities. He is able to walk without assistance but has a slow gait with short steps. Mental status examination shows short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lewy bodies are a typical pathological finding in Lewy body dementia (LBD) and multiple system atrophy, which are both Parkinson-plus syndromes. In combination with dementia and visual hallucinations, parkinsonism indicates a Parkinson-plus syndrome. Poor response to levodopa is also a common feature of this condition. In LBD, dementia typically occurs earlier and is more pronounced, while motor dysfunction is more pronounced at the onset of Parkinson disease. Other characteristic features of LBD include abnormal sleep behavior and cognitive fluctuations.

In patients with multiple system atrophy, autonomic dysfunction and cerebellar symptoms are more dominant than dementia.
Image Description:

Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia can present with dementia, behavioral changes, and loss of cognitive function (e.g., disorientation), but the onset is typically abrupt with stepwise deterioration. Other findings, such as focal neurologic deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, dysarthria), would also be expected. In addition, parkinsonism and visual hallucinations are uncommon with vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Temporal and frontal lobe atrophy is seen in patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Early changes in behavior and personality (e.g., irritability, failure to observe social etiquette) are characteristic of FTD but dementia and parkinsonism typically occur in the late stages of the disease. In addition, FTD typically manifests earlier, usually between the ages of 40 and 60 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Prions are the underlying cause of prion diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Dementia and visual hallucinations may occur as a result, but prion disease progresses extremely rapidly and other findings, e.g., myoclonus and seizures, would be expected as well.

E) INCORRECT:

Longstanding alcohol use disorder is associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is caused by a severe deficiency of thiamine. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome can manifest with symptoms of disorientation, hallucinations, and gait ataxia, but another typical feature is ocular motor dysfunction, which this patient lacks (although his blank stare could be mistaken for ophthalmoplegia). Furthermore, this patient does not have a history or signs of chronic alcohol use disorder (e.g., spider angiomata, gynecomastia), making Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Impaired absorption of CSF and resulting ventriculomegaly is the proposed mechanism underlying normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This condition is characterized by dementia and gait abnormalities. However, urinary incontinence, which this patient lacks, would also be expected. Moreover, visual hallucinations are not typically seen in NPH.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: This patient seems to have had a poor response to levodopa.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of multiple falls and increasing forgetfulness over the past year. During this time, she also has had blurred and double vision. For the past 3 months, her husband notes that he has had difficulty understanding her speech. She has also become withdrawn and refuses to go to social gatherings. She occasionally becomes confused in the evenings. Her blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg when supine and 124/80 mm Hg while standing. Examination shows a broad-based gait and difficulty maintaining balance while standing upright and walking. Neurologic examination shows bradykinesia, dysarthria, and palmar grasp reflex bilaterally. Muscle tone is increased in the upper extremities. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. There is conjugate limitation of both eyes when looking down. Mental status examination shows apathy. The patient responds to questions with 1–2 words after a delay of several seconds. MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) can manifest with signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., frequent falls, gait disturbances, and dysarthria) and parkinsonism (e.g., postural instability). Apathy, frontal lobe release signs (e.g., positive grasp reflex), and signs of dementia (sundowning, social withdrawal, forgetfulness) are typically not seen in MSA because the frontal lobe and other regions of the cortex are usually spared. In addition, MSA typically manifests with features of autonomic dysfunction such as urinary incontinence and orthostatic hypotension. MRI of the brain can show atrophy of the cerebellum and brainstem, and the hot cross bun sign, which is a common but unspecific finding in patients with MSA.

B) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease (AD) is characterized by progressive memory loss. Language impairment, temporal and spatial disorientation, and apathy may also be present as AD progresses. AD does not typically cause motor dysfunction (e.g., bradykinesia, broad-based gait), oculomotor dysfunction, or upper extremity hypertonia.

C) CORRECT:

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disease that belongs to the Parkinson-plus syndromes. PSP is characterized by oculomotor deficits such as vertical gaze palsy (due to atrophy of structures in the tectum of the midbrain), which can progress to complete supranuclear ophthalmoplegia. Patients with PSP often have postural instability, which leads to gait impairment and frequent falls. Frontal lobe dysfunction can manifest with behavioral changes (e.g., apathy, disinhibition, impaired reasoning) and dementia (forgetfulness, social withdrawal, sundowning). Patients usually also present with parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, rigor) and may develop features of pseudobulbar palsy such as dysarthria and dysphagia. The prognosis of PSP is generally poor and most patients die within 5–10 years of symptom onset.

See “Overview of Parkinson-plus syndromes” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) can manifest with features of parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity), frequent falls, and signs of dementia (forgetfulness, sundowning, and especially visuospatial deficits and executive dysfunction). DLB is also characterized by visual hallucinations, delusions, or episodes of paranoia. Dysarthria is not commonly seen.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with symptoms of cognitive disturbance (e.g., apathy, confusion) and gait impairment with a broad-based gait. Hypertonia (due to paratonia or spasticity), bradykinesia, and frontal release signs (e.g., grasp reflex) may also be present. NPH typically does not result in dysarthria or oculomotor dysfunction. In addition, patients with NPH usually present with urinary incontinence. MRI of the brain typically shows ventriculomegaly.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

F) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease (PD) can manifest with motor dysfunction (e.g., frequent falls, bradykinesia, broad-based gait), signs of dementia (e.g., forgetfulness), and apathy. This patient does not, however, have other typical signs of PD, such as resting tremor, rigidity, and hyposmia.
questions.hint: This patient's MRI shows midbrain atrophy with an intact pons, which is also referred to as the hummingbird sign (or penguin sign).

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of progressive difficulty walking during the past 3 months. He has not been able to walk without assistance for the past month and has started to use a wheelchair. He also reports having urinary incontinence for 1 year. His wife says that he has begun to slur his words and has become very difficult to understand. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 16/min. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg while sitting and 110/65 mm Hg when standing. He is alert and fully oriented. Neurological examination shows a mild tremor in his right hand and rigidity in his upper and lower extremities. He is unable to perform repetitive rotary forearm movements. Cranial nerves are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Multiple system atrophy is a neurodegenerative disease that belongs to the Parkinson-plus syndromes. It is characterized by motor abnormalities (tremor and rigidity), autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension and urinary incontinence), and cerebellar symptoms (dysdiadochokinesia, gait disturbances, dysarthria). This patient meets all three criteria, making this the most likely diagnosis. Treatment is largely supportive because Parkinsonian drugs such as levodopa or dopamine agonists are ineffective. Poor response to levodopa is a finding that differentiates Parkinson-plus syndrome from classic Parkinson disease.

See “Overview of Parkinson-plus syndromes” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative disease that can lead to resting tremors, rigidity, and gait disturbances. Though this diagnosis cannot be entirely excluded, the presence of early autonomic dysfunction (urinary incontinence and orthostatic hypotension) and prominent cerebellar involvement (dysdiadochokinesia and dysarthria) makes another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Friedreich ataxia is a neurodegenerative disease that leads to progressive ataxia and dysarthria. In some patients, it may also cause urinary incontinence. However, symptom onset is typically at a much younger age (usually < 25 years) and would be uncommon in a 54-year-old. Additionally, patients typically present with skeletal deformities (scoliosis, foot deformity) and signs of heart failure (palpitations, arrhythmias, dyspnea) secondary to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticobasal degeneration belongs to the Parkinson-plus syndromes and is a rare neurodegenerative disease that causes dementia, asymmetric motor abnormalities (initially affecting only one limb), and “alien limb phenomenon” (in which the patient perceives affected limbs as not belonging to him/her). Though this patient also has motor dysfunction, he does not have any other signs of corticobasal degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) can cause urinary incontinence and gait abnormalities. However, NPH also causes cognitive disturbances and would not explain this patient's cerebellar dysfunction (dysdiadochokinesia), tremor, or muscle rigidity.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

F) INCORRECT:

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) belongs to the Parkinson-plus syndromes and is a neurodegenerative disease that causes postural instability and dysarthria. However, the two most defining symptoms of PSP are frontal lobe dysfunction (causing e.g., disinhibition) and vertical gaze palsy, which are both absent in this patient.
questions.hint: Which disease is characterized by a triad of motor abnormalities, autonomic dysfunction, and cerebellar symptoms?

questions.text: An 81-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter after he was found wandering on the street. For the last 3 months, he often has a blank stare for several minutes. He also claims to have seen strangers in the house on several occasions who were not present. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 8 months ago. His current medications include carbidopa-levodopa, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. He has short-term memory deficits and appears confused and disheveled. Examination shows bilateral muscle rigidity and resting tremor in his upper extremities. He has a slow gait with short steps. Microscopic examination of the cortex of a patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Histopathological findings of intracellular Lewy bodies in the cortex are found in patients with Parkinson disease or some Parkinson-plus syndromes. New-onset dementia, early onset of gait abnormalities, and a poor response to levodopa in a patient with parkinsonism should raise suspicion of a Parkinson-plus syndrome. This patient's visual hallucinations are especially consistent with Lewy body dementia, the second most common form of neurodegenerative dementia. Another Parkinson-plus syndrome associated with Lewy bodies is multiple system atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a prion disease that causes dementia and visual hallucinations, as seen in this patient. However, the disease progresses extremely rapidly and other findings, such as myoclonus and seizures, would be expected as well. In addition, the biopsy shown in this case does not show prions.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia may present with dementia and loss of cognitive function (e.g., disorientation), but the onset is typically abrupt with stepwise deterioration. Moreover, vascular dementia does not cause visual hallucinations, and focal neurologic deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, dysarthria) would be expected. Vascular dementia also does not explain the biopsy findings.
Image Description:

Frontal section of the brain at the level of the optical chiasma (dashed blue overlay) showing hemorrhage and infarction (examples indicated by green circles) in the region of the basal ganglia. As a result, there is reduced demarcation of the internal capsule (dashed white outline) between the caudate (yellow overlay) and lentiform nuclei (blue overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is caused by impaired absorption of CSF and resulting ventriculomegaly. This condition is characterized by dementia and gait abnormalities. However, another typical feature is urinary incontinence, which this patient lacks. Moreover, the biopsy and visual hallucinations are inconsistent with NPH.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia also causes dementia and parkinsonism. However, unlike in this patient, these findings typically manifest in the late stages of disease. Instead, early changes in behavior and personality (e.g., irritability, failure to observe social etiquette) and primary progressive aphasia, which are cardinal signs of frontotemporal dementia, would be expected. Biopsy findings of frontotemporal dementia would also show inclusions of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins (called Pick bodies) or ubiquitinated TDP-43. In addition, frontotemporal dementia typically manifests between the ages of 40–60.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an anterior cingulate cortex tissue specimen (immunohistochemistry for tau-protein; 100x magnification, insert 600x magnification)

There is a decrease in neuron density as an expression of neurodegeneration. Multiple positively stained (brown) paranuclear inclusion bodies are seen (example in insert).

These pick bodies (intracytoplasmic inclusions of tau fibrils) are seen in a subtype of frontotemporal lobar degeneration.
questions.hint: Histopathological findings show intracellular eosinophilic inclusions composed of α-synuclein. This finding with visual hallucinations is a common combination in this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with no prior psychiatric history presents at the request of her daughter, who reports that her mother has managed the family’s business for several years but has recently begun to snap at customers and occasionally has other trouble, such as forgetting where things are placed around the store. Symptoms have progressed mainly during the past 3 to 6 months. When carefully asked, the daughter feels that subtle changes may have been present for up to a year, although her mother has some days where she behaves normally and some days when she has a lot more difficulty.
The patient believes that several customers are watching her and planning to break into her home. She also reports seeing animals and men in uniform at night when she tries to sleep, although she recognizes that these visions are not real.
The physical examination is normal, but the patient has difficulty copying intersecting pentagons and repeating digits backwards. She denies changes in sleep, energy, or appetite and reports no suicidal or homicidal ideation.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dementia is characterized by functionally impairing deficits in at least two cognitive domains. Dementia with Lewy bodies tends to cause deficits in attention and visuospatial sense, whereas Alzheimer disease predominantly causes memory deficits. For a diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies, patients must have at least two of the following core criteria in addition to dementia:

• Fluctuating cognition with great variations in attention and alertness from day to day or even hour to hour
• Recurrent visual hallucinations (observed in 75% of people who have dementia with Lewy bodies)
• Motor features of Parkinson disease
• Rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder

The presence of psychosis (delusions, paranoia), visual hallucinations, and personality change early in the course of dementia is common in patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies. With this condition, the loss of cholinergic neurons is thought to account for degeneration of cognitive function (similar to Alzheimer disease), whereas the death of dopaminergic neurons appears to be responsible for degeneration of motor control (similar to Parkinson disease).

Key learning point: Dementia with early-onset psychotic symptoms, visual hallucinations, and personality change is most consistent with a diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies tends to cause deficits in attention and visuospatial sense, whereas Alzheimer disease predominantly causes memory deficits. The presence of psychosis (delusions, paranoia), visual hallucinations, and personality change early in the course of dementia is common in patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypnagogic hallucinations or delusions occur while falling asleep and are not associated with daytime memory impairment or paranoia.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizophrenia is characterized by psychotic symptoms, but rarely surfaces late in life and is not associated with significant memory impairment at initial presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms, but rarely surfaces late in life and is not associated with significant memory impairment at initial presentation.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man with no significant medical history presents with cognitive dysfunction and shuffling gait. During the past 2 years, his family has observed gradually progressive cognitive decline, with fluctuating periods of inattention or confusion and uncharacteristic errors in calculation and spelling. His memory is generally preserved. During the past 3 months, the family notes that he has developed visual hallucinations. They also note that his face is less expressive and his body movements have slowed. In recent months, he has had short periods of talking and flailing in his sleep. He takes no medications.
Physical examination reveals muscle rigidity in his torso and a shuffling gait. His score on the Mini-Mental State Examination is 20, consistent with mild-to-moderate cognitive impairment. The remainder of the physical examination is normal, as is routine laboratory testing.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease generally do not present with parkinsonian motor symptoms, and their motor function usually remains intact until very late in the course of their disease. In Alzheimer disease, problems with short-term memory tend to be the most prominent early manifestations of cognitive impairment, whereas in dementia with Lewy bodies, the prominent early findings tend to be impairments of attention and visuospatial perception.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with idiopathic Parkinson disease often develop dementia at some point, but cognitive decline typically becomes noticeable after — not before — the onset of motor symptoms. Visual hallucinations can occur in Parkinson disease, but they are less common, particularly early in the disease course.

C) INCORRECT:

The dementia in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease progresses more rapidly (within 6 to 12 months) than the 2 years described in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease can develop cognitive impairment and parkinsonian symptoms, but onset is usually in adolescence or young adulthood.

E) CORRECT:

Fluctuating cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian symptoms and signs are hallmarks of dementia with Lewy bodies. In typical cases of this condition, cognitive decline precedes the appearance of parkinsonian motor symptoms. The decline is typically marked by problems with executive function and attention rather than memory, as memory tends to be spared early in the course of the illness. The parkinsonian symptoms seen in dementia with Lewy bodies include masked face, bradykinesia, rigidity, and gait impairment; tremor is less common than in idiopathic Parkinson disease. Vocalizations and dream enactment behavior during sleep are symptoms of REM sleep behavior disorder, which is frequently associated with dementia with Lewy bodies.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in patients with fluctuating cognitive decline, parkinsonian symptoms and signs, and visual hallucinations is dementia with Lewy bodies.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with no significant medical or psychiatric history presents with his wife, who says that for the past 3 weeks, he has been hallucinating that goats and pigs are inside the house. During the past 6 months, he sleeps a lot during the day and can be very difficult to rouse, but he does not snore. He has also had problems telling time, recently got lost on his way to the neighborhood grocery store, and has had several near-falls, all in the past 6 months. He has otherwise been asymptomatic, with no fever or any constitutional symptoms. He does not drink and does not report any symptoms of depression.
On a Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination, the patient scores 25 out of 30 (the low end of the normal range), having lost points on copying intersecting pentagons, following 3-step commands, and performing calculations. His orientation, language, and delayed recall are normal. He has substantial impairment on a clock-drawing test.
His cranial-nerve findings, including extraocular eye movements, are normal. He is hypophonic and bradykinetic. He has rigidity in all extremities, including cogwheeling at the wrist, but no resting tremor. His power, sensation, coordination, and deep-tendon reflexes are normal in all extremities. He walks in a stooped posture with festination.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies, among the most common causes of dementia in older adults after Alzheimer disease and vascular dementia, is characterized pathologically by the presence of Lewy bodies, clumps of alpha-synuclein and ubiquitin proteins in neurons. Dementia with Lewy bodies manifests with a varying combination of parkinsonism, dementia, visual hallucinations, and fluctuating cognition. The patient often has a stooped posture, hypophonic speech, slow movements, rigidity, and a shuffling gait. Other possible features are sleep abnormalities and neuroleptic sensitivity, the latter of which can lead to a severely confused and rigid state that may be irreversible. Dementia is either present at onset or develops within a year after the onset of parkinsonian symptoms. In particular, visuospatial cognition is impaired, which can lead to people getting lost in familiar areas, and can be tested by having the patient copy intersecting pentagons.

Among age- and education-matched patients with dementia, patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies typically exhibit more impairment in visuospatial tasks, attention, and executive function than do patients with Alzheimer disease.

Key learning point: The combination of parkinsonism, early dementia, fluctuations in cognition, and visual hallucinations is most consistent with a diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

The absence of abnormalities in vertical eye movements and axial rigidity make progressive supranuclear palsy less likely. Fluctuating cognitive impairment and visual hallucinations are not typical features of progressive supranuclear palsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is characterized by episodic memory impairment early in the disease course; parkinsonian features, fluctuating cognition, and hallucinations are typically late manifestations if they occur at all.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with corticobasal syndrome have parkinsonian signs and symptoms that may be difficult to distinguish from dementia with Lewy bodies, but these patients usually have coexisting aphasia, apraxia, dystonia, or alien-limb syndrome, and these findings are often asymmetric. Fluctuating cognitive impairment and visual hallucinations are not typical features of corticobasal syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

In idiopathic Parkinson disease, dementia surfaces years to decades after the onset of motor symptoms. Hallucinations and fluctuations in cognition are not usually an issue early on in the disease.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man who has dementia with Lewy bodies is brought in by his wife. She has noticed worsening of the patient's cognition, most notably in his short-term memory and his ability to navigate to the correct room in their house. The patient has been spending more time sleeping in the living room chair; when he is awake, he experiences hallucinations and agitation and has engaged in behavior that is threatening to others. Redirection, cognitive stimulation, and reorientation have not been effective.
Which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clonazepam is an adjunct treatment for the sleep-behavior abnormalities observed in some patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies; it is not indicated for neurobehavioral manifestations.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies are exquisitely sensitive to neuroleptics such as haloperidol. Because these drugs may induce overt psychoses and potentially irreversible rigidity, they should be avoided in this clinical setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Most patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies have parkinsonian symptoms and signs. A dopamine agonist such as levodopa-carbidopa might improve motor symptoms, but it would have little effect on behavioral and cognitive symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies are exquisitely sensitive to neuroleptics such as risperidone. Because these drugs may induce overt psychoses and potentially irreversible rigidity, they should be avoided in this clinical setting.

E) CORRECT:

Striking deficits in cholinergic neurotransmission are seen in the brains of patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies (and are greater than those seen in patients with Alzheimer dementia); therefore, drugs enhancing central cholinergic function represent a rational therapeutic approach to this disorder. Donepezil, a cholinesterase inhibitor, has been shown to improve neuropsychological performance and reduce apathy and hallucinations in patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies and is frequently used for this purpose, although it has not been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for this indication.

Key learning point: The best medication class for managing the neurobehavioral manifestations of dementia with Lewy bodies is a cholinesterase inhibitor.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents with progressive forgetfulness over the past year. His wife notes intermittent disorientation and forgetfulness during daily tasks. He reports visual hallucinations of children playing in the living room. Examination shows a resting tremor and a slow, shuffling gait, but no focal weakness. Routine laboratory tests are normal.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by early changes in personality, behavior, and language, rather than memory impairment. The presence of visual hallucinations and parkinsonian features, such as a resting tremor and shuffling gait, is atypical for frontotemporal dementia, which usually presents with behavioral and language abnormalities.

B) CORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) manifests with early cognitive impairment, fluctuating attention, and pronounced visual hallucinations, alongside parkinsonian motor signs. This patient exhibits visual hallucinations, a resting tremor, and a shuffling gait, supporting the diagnosis. DLB involves abnormal alpha-synuclein deposition as Lewy bodies, affecting cortical regions and leading to both cognitive and motor symptoms. Cognitive decline in DLB often occurs concurrently or soon after parkinsonism, unlike Parkinson disease dementia, where motor symptoms precede dementia by at least a year. The absence of focal neurological deficits and normal laboratory tests further support DLB.

Key learning point: Dementia with Lewy bodies is characterized by Parkinsonism, early dementia, cognitive fluctuations, and visual hallucinations.

C) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease dementia involves cognitive decline following a prolonged period of Parkinsonian motor symptoms. In this patient, cognitive impairment and visual hallucinations developed within the past year, suggesting concurrent cognitive and motor symptoms, which is more typical of dementia with Lewy bodies rather than Parkinson disease dementia.

D) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease typically presents with gradual memory decline and deficits in language, visuospatial abilities, and executive function. However, vivid visual hallucinations and parkinsonian signs, such as a resting tremor and shuffling gait, are not characteristic early features of Alzheimer disease. These symptoms are more indicative of dementia with Lewy bodies.

questions.text: You are seeing a 74-year-old man who presents with a 2-year history of gradually worsening cognitive dysfunction and shuffling gait. His family reports fluctuating periods of inattention or confusion, as well as uncharacteristic errors in calculation and spelling. His memory is generally preserved. Over the past 3 months, he has developed visual hallucinations and his family has noticed reduced facial expressiveness. Recently, he has had brief episodes of talking and flailing during sleep. On examination, there is muscle rigidity in his torso and a shuffling gait. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 20, indicating mild-to-moderate cognitive impairment. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with idiopathic Parkinson disease often develop dementia at some point, but cognitive decline typically becomes noticeable after — not before — the onset of motor symptoms. Visual hallucinations can occur in Parkinson disease, but they are less common, particularly early in the disease course.

B) CORRECT:

Fluctuating cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian symptoms and signs are hallmarks of dementia with Lewy bodies. In typical cases of this condition, cognitive decline precedes the appearance of parkinsonian motor symptoms. The decline is typically marked by problems with executive function and attention rather than memory, as memory tends to be spared early in the course of the illness. The parkinsonian symptoms seen in dementia with Lewy bodies include masked face, bradykinesia, rigidity, and gait impairment; tremor is less common than in idiopathic Parkinson disease. Vocalizations and dream enactment behavior during sleep are symptoms of REM sleep behavior disorder, which is frequently associated with dementia with Lewy bodies.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in patients with fluctuating cognitive decline, parkinsonian symptoms and signs, and visual hallucinations is dementia with Lewy bodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease generally do not present with parkinsonian motor symptoms, and their motor function usually remains intact until very late in the course of their disease. In Alzheimer disease, problems with short-term memory tend to be the most prominent early manifestations of cognitive impairment, whereas in dementia with Lewy bodies, the prominent early findings tend to be impairments of attention and visuospatial perception.

D) INCORRECT:

The dementia in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease progresses more rapidly (within 6 to 12 months) than the 2 years described in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease can develop cognitive impairment and parkinsonian symptoms, but onset is usually in adolescence or young adulthood.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and previous myocardial infarction is brought to the emergency department by his family after a fall at home. His wife reports he has become increasingly unsteady, experiences frequent falls, and has developed difficulty walking over the past 6 months. He has been taking quetiapine 25 mg daily for several years for agitation with no recent dose changes. Physical examination shows postural instability and bilateral lower extremity bradykinesia and spasticity with involuntary variable resistance during passive movement. Mental status examination shows mild cognitive impairment with executive dysfunction and poor attention. MRI brain shows multiple periventricular white matter lesions and lacunar infarcts in the basal ganglia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient demonstrates classic features of vascular parkinsonism including an advanced age (>70 years), multiple cardiovascular risk factors, gait impairment as the primary presenting symptom, bilateral, symmetric parkinsonism limited to the lower extremities, and spasticity that is greater than rigidity. Involuntary variable resistance during passive movement (paratonia) and cognitive impairment may also occur in vascular parkinsonism. The MRI findings of multiple periventricular lesions and lacunar infarcts in the basal ganglia are pathognomonic and support this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced parkinsonism typically develops within weeks to months of medication initiation or dose increase. This patient has been on a stable low dose of quetiapine for several years without recent changes, making drug-induced parkinsonism unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies typically manifests with prominent cognitive decline as the primary feature, often accompanied by visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and REM sleep behavior disorder. While parkinsonism may occur in dementia with Lewy bodies, it manifests with bradykinesia, rest tremor, and rigidity, unlike this patient’s symmetric, lower extremity-predominant presentation with spasticity and paratonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease typically manifests with asymmetric onset of bradykinesia and resting tremor, usually beginning in the upper extremities. This patient's bilateral, symmetric presentation limited to the lower extremities, presence of spasticity and paratonia, and the characteristic vascular imaging findings are not consistent with idiopathic Parkinson disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticobasal degeneration typically manifests with markedly asymmetric parkinsonism, upper limb clumsiness, and features such as alien limb phenomenon and ideomotor apraxia. This patient's bilateral, symmetric, lower extremity-predominant symptoms and lack of cortical features make corticobasal degeneration unlikely. Additionally, MRI findings in corticobasal degeneration characteristically show asymmetric focal cortical atrophy and atrophy of the basal ganglia. These findings differ from this patient's subcortical vascular lesions.
